title: Money launderer wants to join Hong Kong protests
text:
A Melbourne man who laundered $4.6 million through a bogus meat exporting business has confided in lawyers that he hopes to join protesters in Hong Kong after serving jail time in Australia.

Kit Tang, 42, ordered staff at export business CC &B International to carry bags of cash – as much as $530,000 at a time – down the street to a Commonwealth Bank of Australia branch in Springvale in 2015. He then funnelled the money back to his bosses in Hong Kong.

At a hearing on Tuesday morning, County Court of Victoria Judge Michael Cahill said Tang faced jail time and would be deported back to Hong Kong after serving his prison sentence.

"I asked him what he planned to do when he returned to Hong Kong and with a very a very straight face, he said protest," Tang's barrister Alan Marshall told Judge Cahill.

Tang pleaded guilty to five charges related to money laundering and has been out on bail for the past four years. He faces three years in prison and will be sentenced on November 12.

CC &B fronted as a meat exporter but was actually used by clients to hide their identity when they wanted to make a cash deposit and transfer the money overseas to siblings Billy and Connie Leung, prosecutors allege.
description: A Melbourne man who laundered $4.6 million through a bogus meat exporting business has confided in lawyers that he hopes to join protesters in Hong Kong after serving jail time in Australia.
